dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a finger pressing the "record" button of a circa 1970's tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Harvey Milk speaking on Friday November 18th. This is to be played only in the event of my death by assassination... REVEAL: HARVEY MILK, 48, sitting at his kitchen table in cluttered San Francisco apartment.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: During one of the early campaigns, I started opening my speeches with the same line and it sort of became my signature...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In street clothes, trying to corral an angry mob on City Hall's steps, Harvey lifts a bullhorn.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Harvey Milk, and I'm here to recruit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey at his kitchen table making his recording...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If I was speaking to a slightly hostile or mostly straight audience, I'd try to break the tension with a joke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is in a plain, ill fitting brown suit making a CAMPAIGN SPEECH to a crowd of stone faced UNION BOYS.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I know, I know, I'm not what you were expecting, but I left my high heels at home. Harvey gets a LAUGH from the AUDIENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RETURN TO: Harvey speaking into his tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I fully realize that a person who stands for what I stand for - an activist, a gay activist - becomes the target or potential target for a person who is insecure, terrified, afraid or very disturbed themselves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE OFFICERS AND PRESS RACE THROUGH THE HALLS of City Hall, their walkie-talkies squawking. Something terrible happened. It's chaos. A STRETCHER IS WHEELED OUT OF AN OFFICE. On it, a FILLED BAG with a WHITE SHEET draped over it. The press rush to get a shot. The police officers quickly load the body onto the elevator and disappear from sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shell shocked DIANNE FEINSTEIN, 45, wades into a throng REPORTERS. Those surrounding her try to quiet the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE FEINSTEIN
dialogues.text: As President of the Board of Supervisors, it's my duty to make this announcement. Both Mayor Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk have been shot... and killed. GASPS from the REPORTERS. Dianne struggles to be heard.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE FEINSTEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Police are looking for a suspect... Supervisor Dan White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very picture of loveliness, MARY-ANN WHITE, 28, finds husband DAN WHITE, 31, sitting in the pews praying. He's handsome, devout, all-American man in a three-piece suit. She sits by him. A weight hangs. He can't make eye contac

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Something has happened.
She puts her arm around him, feels a gun at his side. She holds him, firmly gripping the revolver in his holster, t conceal, to keep him from using it, potentially on himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RETURN TO: Harvey speaking into his tape recorder...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Knowing that I could be assassinated at any moment, I feel it's important that some people should understand my thoughts. I think that-- (pauses, not sure what to say) I wish I had time to explain everything I did. Almost everything that was done was done with an eye on the gay movement.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO BLACK
dialogues.text: CLEAN WHITE LETTERS ON A BLACK SCREEN READ ГўВЂВњMILK"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: "New York City. 1970." HARVEY, 40, is HEADING UP THE STAIRS from the subway platform. He is wearing a SUIT, but he's less than clean His hair is brushing past his ears. HARVEY'S VERY INTERESTED POV: SCOTT SMITH, 22, a sexy cur haired hippie in tight jeans and boots, is HEADING DOWN T THE STAIRS. Harvey tries to make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hey. I'm Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (so what?) Okay, Harvey...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Today's my birthday. (Scott laughs) No, today is actually my birthday. Well, tonight. At midnight.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And, believe it or not, I don't have any plans. People took me out after work...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (looking him over) Work? So, that would be... Let me guess. Ma Bell or AT&T.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The Great American Insurance Company. I'm part of the big, evil, corporate establishment that, let me guess, you think is the cause of every evil thing in the world from Vietnam to diaper rash.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: You left out bad breath. Falling for it, Harvey covers his mouth. Scott laughs. Th both smile, realizing they share a wry sense of humor. A TRAIN IS COMING, Harvey has to work fast.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: So... You're not going to let me celebrate my birthday all by myself are you?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (gently teasing) Listen, Harvey, you're kind of cute for a suit... But I don't do guys over forty.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well then, I'm in luck.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Because I'm still thirty-nine... (showing Scott his watch) And it's only eleven-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN A TIGHT TWO-SHOT, Scott is pressed against a wall with Harvey pressed against his back having sex. Harvey is the aggressor, completely uninhibited.
OPERA MUSIC PLAYS on a record player. (Wagner's Tristan a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey feeds Scott spoonfuls of CREAM PIE from a TRAY FUL FOOD that rests on the bed between them. Ice cream, cooki milk, berries... It's over the top and adorable.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Jackson, Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well, this isn't Jackson, but you still can't respond to every strange man you meet on a subway platform. It's too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Now you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: There's nothing tougher than a New York City cop. They're arrogant, and they're everywhere. I'll show you the cruising spots, if you want, if you promise you'll be careful... little Scottie-san.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Are you on uppers or what?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No. This is just... plain old me.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: You're afraid of the cops?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm just discreet. I know a lot of people here. If they found out, I could lose my job.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (meaning a closet case) Oh. You're one of "those." (examines Harvey's eyes) I think you need a change of scenery. New friends.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I need a change.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (looks at the clock) You're forty now.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (just the truth) Forty years old and I haven't done a thing I'm proud of.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (re: the desert tray) You keep eating like this and you'll be a fat ass by fifty.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (laughs it off) No. Don't you worry. I won't make it to fifty. Scott distracts him, playful, like a newlywed at a weddin he rubs a slice of pie in Harvey's face. Harvey reacts. Wipes the pie from his eye, and tackles hi young, frisky new lover. They kiss. The mess getting everywhere. Harvey brushes it out of Scott's hair.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (an idea, half-jokingly,

dialogues.speaker: HALF-SERIOUSLY
dialogues.text: Why don't we run away together?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RETURN TO: Harvey speaks to the tape recorder. (Throughou the film, these scenes should feel intimate, as if Harvey telling us things no one else knows.)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: In those days, San Francisco was the place where everyone wanted to go... To drop out... To fall in love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8MM HOME MOVIE MONTAGE of Harvey and Scott DRESSED FULL-O LIKE HIPPIES, long hair, beard, beads, sunglasses, drivin
through the redwoods, over the Golden Gate Bridge, and in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But by 1972, The Haight was boarded up. Crime-filled. Drug-filled. The new place for us refugees was this run down Irish Catholic neighborhood in Eureka Valley. Six blocks square... The Castro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey lifts a Nikon camera and starts SNAPPING PHOTOS of Castro Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a LIQUOR STORE, empty buildings, boarded windows... Harvey points the camera toward The MARQUEE of the Castro Theater, big letters spelling out... "C A S T R O..." Harvey points his camera across the street at the gray- haired, OWNER of a liquor store. Harvey snaps PHOTOS of h face, an expression of distrust. Harvey SNAPS a SIGN in the liquor shop window that reads:

dialogues.speaker: "EUREKA VALLEY MERCHANTS SOCIETY."
dialogues.text: Harvey's CAMERA focuses on TWO CUTE, YOUNG, HIPPIE BOYS WALKING PAST, one puts his arm over the other. To Harvey' eyes it's a very new site. It's overt. Thrilling. Harvey snaps a photo of an empty storefront with a FOR RE SIGN hanging out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is FILLED with OPERA MUSIC from a record player Harvey is loading a roll of film into his camera. Scott is getting high, lying in the sun that pours throug the large, empty windows.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I cashed my last unemployment check yesterday...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you did something useful with it.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I bought an ounce of pot. I was just wondering if you had any (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: plans, or thoughts... About us doing something to, you know, bring in an income.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Don't move. Harvey straddles Scott. He begins SNAPPING PHOTOS of him.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I suppose I can wait tables.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: No way. I want you right here with me... Did you see place downstairs is for rent?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I was thinking we could open a shop together.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: What kind of shop?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: One with very little overhead. Not too much work... A little one, just like Morris and Minnie Milk of Woodmere, New York...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's empty store front has been converted to a CAMERA STORE (with a few, not very impressive, products). Harvey is out on the sidewalk directing Scott who is insi the store's large window hanging a sign: "CASTRO CAMERA."

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Just a little to the left... The old liquor store owner from earlier, MCCONNELLY, cros the street to watch. Harvey gives him a warm welcome:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello there. I'm Harvey Milk.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELLY
dialogues.text: You're the new renters?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Yes. Welcome to Castro Camera.
Harvey extends his hand. McConnelly shakes, but is wary.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to join the, um... What is it? The Eureka Valley Merchant's Association. I want to help in any way possible. I'm no interloper. A Jew perhaps, but I hope you'll forgive that. McConnelly looks from Harvey to Scott in the window.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELLY
dialogues.text: I don't think your application will be approved, Mr. Milk. This is a family neighborhood. Your kind are far more welcome on Haight street.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (trying to keep it friendly) What "kind" do you mean, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELLY
dialogues.text: (not playing along) The Merchant's Association will have the police pull your license if you open your doors.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Based on what law?

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELLY
dialogues.text: There's man's law and there's God's law in this neighborhood and in this City. The San Francisco Police force is happy to enforce either.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (to McConnelly as he walks away) Thanks for the warm welcome to the neighborhood!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: We pay taxes you know! Harvey grabs Scott's hand... keeps him from heating up, f pouncing. It's not the time for them to bite yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott is sitting on the bed, while Harvey is TALKING A MI MINUTE FROM THE KITCHEN, totally energized.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We'll form our own business association! Start with the gay- owned businesses... We'll take down the addresses of every customer that comes in for a roll of film. We'll ask them what they want to see done here... what they want changed... We'll get money rolling into this neighborhood. Revitalize it...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Can I come in now?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: One more minute! (back to his new scheme) I'll go to the neighborhood banks. They must have some gay customers.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey. What's with all this political activist crap? I thought you were a goddamn Republican. Harvey walks into the small dining room holding two plate food. He sets them out on a small dining room table, stil rambling on to Scott in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm a businessman, Scott. I think businesses ought to treat their customers right. Even their gay customers. For God's sake, this is San Francisco!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey. It's just like every other city in this country. People hate us. Big surprise.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We should have at least one block in one city right? Start there and take over the neighborhood. (a smile) Okay, you can come in now! Scott heads toward the kitchen. The table is LAID OUT wit home-cooked meal, CANDLES and a huge bouquet of FLOWERS.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Wow. This is--
Harvey SMASHES A CREAM PIE into Scott's face. Payback.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Happy birthday! Scott chases Harvey around the apartment, trying to smear some of the CREAM PIE onto him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is shut down for the first ever Castro Street Fair. The crowd is mostly gay, the majority congregate outside Toad Hall bar. ANGLE ON: SOME OF THE OLD-SCHOOL, IRISH LOCALS milling ab eyeing the scene skeptically. Harvey MOVES THROUGH THE CROWD with Scott, shaking hands.

dialogues.speaker: MAN ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: Thanks for the party, Mr. Milk!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Thanks for joining the Castro Village Association! Harvey arrives at A LONG LINE OF GAY MEN winding out of t Irish liquor store (from earlier). He squeezes past them, into the store, leaving Scott outside.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me gentleman... ladies. (finding the shop owner) Hello! Mr. McConnelly! McConnelly, at the register, is overwhelmed with all the business.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just wanted to stop in and see how business was doing.

dialogues.speaker: MCCONNELLY
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: So you don't mind all these homosexuals in here, do you? McConnelly grins, uncomfortable. The line of gay men is curious about the hubbub. Point made, Harvey does a 180.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. No. Just a joke. Mr. McConnelly here loves our kind. Spend away! (to McConnelly) Tell your wife Hello for me. Harvey spots Scott in the crowd and PULLS HIM TOWARD HIM, KISSING HIM ON THE MOUTH. It's quite the show. They step back out onto the street where an Irish band is now playi Gay men watch. Some clap. Harvey grabs Scott and spins hi through a sharp waltz. OFF the pair at home in their new neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And people started hanging around our store. Not customers. Activists, kids, folks who needed a home away from home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEW sign goes in the window: "We are VERY open."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW YOUNG MEN are hanging out in the shop, the beginnin of Harvey's entourage. Harvey moves among them, sharing a clipped Sunday cartoon, lecturing them on politics or the arts, and checking out the cute ones.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There was Danny Niccoletta, a cute art student who I'd picked up at Toad Hall. Turns out he was also good at running the Camera Shop... something Scott and I found we had surprising little interest in... ON DANNY NICCOLETTA, young, waif-like, somewhat helpless.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY NICCOLETTA
dialogues.text: Opera is passe, Harvey. It's about street theater, now.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What you're not getting is the spectacle of it, the bigger than life emotions... Danny jumps up and IMITATES the LARGER THAN LIFE GESTURES an opera diva, making Harvey laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jim Rivaldo. A great mind. A great wit. A Harvard graduate, which nobody cared about, in those days, in the Castro... including himself. JIM RIVALDO flops down into the vintage dental chair that sits in front of Harvey's desk. He seems to be looking fo something to occupy his keen mind. A sharply dressed youn man, 20s, DICK PABICH, walks up to peek over his shoulder

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And somewhere along the line Jim picked up a protege, a cute political kid from Wisconsin... Dick Pabich... And of course there was Dennis Peron, who ran a very popular business with the new kids... DENNIS PERON hands Scott a FREE JOINT.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And on occasion we actually had a real customer. But only occasionally. ACROSS THE ROOM, Scott is waiting on a CUSTOMER, he's out place: straight, gruff, a union man, ALLAN BAIRD, 40s.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey... This guy wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (approaches Allan) Welcome. What can we do for you?

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Allan Baird. Teamsters representative, and Director of the Coors beer boycott in California.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Everyone, this is Allan Baird. He's a very big deal, so behave yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: I was told you were like the Mayor of the Castro, said you organized the CVA, you might know some people in the bars.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I do have friends in awfully low places, but just so you know, it's not official yet.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The Mayor part. I've considered gathering an army of queers to march up to City Hall and secede, but so far the young gays seem more interested in jeeps and jeans. But if I could be of any use, I'm all ears!

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: We can't get Coors to go union. These guys are like me, they can't be out of work too long. Harvey pulls Allan aside, away from the audience, easing nerves. It's Harvey at his best.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm just curious. Are we your first stop or your last?

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: (clearly his last) It's been a tough one, Mr. Milk.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well, you seem to have noticed that my kind of people drink a lot of beer. If we're going to fast for your sake, I think we should get to deliver some of it when you win this fight, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: (INCREDULOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you really want?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And allies. I'll have Coors out of every bar in the Castro by the end of the week. Deal?

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN BAIRD
dialogues.text: (nods, sincere) Thank you Mr. Milk.
JUMP TO: Allan is on his way out. Harvey walks back behin the counter to Scott.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No more Coors beer. It's gotta come out of every bar. Gay and straight.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: What's he giving you?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Nothing for me. That's a convert.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: A convert to what?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STILL PHOTO MONTAGE: Jim, Dick, Scott and Danny get bar owners throughout San Francisco to unscrew their Coors ta throw out their Coors stock, put on "Boycott Coors" butto and tape up "Dump Coors" posters.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I got "my people" to get Coors out of all the Gay Bars. 30 million bottles worth in San Francisco alone. Coors beer immediately fell from number 1. They caved. One week later, union man Allan Baird hired the first ever openly gay union boys to drive Teamsters trucks... We weren't just a group of pansies anymore. We had a neighborhood. We had the unions. And for the first time, we had a little bit of power.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Maybe that was the day someone first called me the "Mayor" of Castro Street. (a knowing grin) Or perhaps I invented it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, Jim & Dick, Scott, Danny and Dennis debate th of working within "the system" versus dropping out. Every is talking over each other...
A YOUNG GAY MAN runs into the store.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GAY MAN
dialogues.text: The fucking cops, man, they're up on Castro Street! Toad Hall. Harvey and the guys race out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, Scott, Jim, Dick, Dennis run up the street toward of the Castro GAY BARS where POLICE ARE GETTING OUT OF SQ CARS AND APPROACHING CUSTOMERS crowding around the entran

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Clear the sidewalk! Some of the GAY MEN move out of the COPS' way but some of them don't move FAST ENOUGH. The COPS start BEATING them. Harvey, Scott and the OTHERS try to break into the crowd, get closer to the fight. To pull the cops off their frien Danny HANGS BACK, snapping PHOTOS of the event. Scott SHOVES his way past the cops. A COP BRINGS HIS NIGH STICK down hard on SCOTT'S HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott sits on the toilet. Harvey rinses blood from a whit washcloth and goes back to cleaning Scott's HEAD WOUND.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: ...if we had someone in the government who saw things the way we see them, the way the black community has black leaders who look out for their interests--

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: You're gonna run for Supervisor, is that the idea?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (HALF-JOKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could go right for mayor, but I think I should work my way up to it... You'll be my campaign manager.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (SARCASTIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have so much experience in politics.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Politics is theater. It doesn't matter if you win. You make a statement. You say, "I'm here, pay attention to me."

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey, you do that every time you cross the street.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Coors looks like it might cave. The union boys will owe me. Imagine if we get their vote... It'll be fun!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Fun? Harvey starts kissing him all over.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We'll make it a spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks down to Market St. with a box. He waves, sha flirts with everyone. His warmest hello is from a gruff U MAN. Behind Harvey, Scott pushes a loaded shopping cart. Harvey sets his box down right beside a SFPD OFFICER. It reads, ГўВЂВњSoap Box.ГўВЂВќ Harvey steps onto it. A crow

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: A week ago, Police officers came into our area with covered up badges and sent fourteen of our people to the hospitals, and to jail. The charges, "Blocking a Sidewalk." Like a round girl at a boxing match, Scott parades around blown up PHOTO from his shopping cart: TWO SF COPS DRAGGI GAY MEN INTO A PADDY WAGON.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --Let us have our tax money go for our protection and not our persecution. Worry about gun control and not marijuana control. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: School supplies, seniors, not what books I read-- Scott displays an old "Muscle Boys" magazine. Harvey does well timed take. A few hoots from the eclectic crowd.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My fellow degenerates, I would like to announce my candidacy for San Francisco City Supervisor! Scott unfurls three hand made "MILK FOR CITY SUPERVISOR" banners that lap over the sides of the shopping cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE SCOTT, DANNY, JIM handing out FLYERS to a variety SF CITIZENS: gay boys, older people, Chinese people, scar straight people, heckling high school boys. Harvey EAGERLY APPROACHES anyone and everyone, shaking ha if they'll let him, reaching out to old people, straight people, gay people, even buttoned down BUSINESSMEN who cr the street to try to get away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey hands out campaign literature to a PASSERSBY.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Public dental care for retired people... Legalize pot, vote Milk. Harvey is distracted. A young, long haired CLEVE JONES passes. At 18, he looks 15. Harvey tries for his attentio

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, I like the way your pants fit... Where are you from, kid?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry old man, not interested.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Where's home?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm Harvey Milk. I'm running for Supervisor. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Cleve... Jones.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well Mr. Jones, we should walk up to my camera shop and register you.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Fuck that. Elections of any kind are a bourgeois affectation.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Is that right? Do you trick up on Polk Street?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (only half-joking) If I need the cash... But I'm selective about my clients.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Tell me one thing before you get back to work then. What was it like to be a little queer in Phoenix?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I faked a lung disease to get out of PE. So what? What are you, some kind of street shrink?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Sometimes. But what I'm saying is, Phoenix can change. But we have to start with our street: rent control, police abuse, pot, parks, seniors.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (turns to go) Well, good luck with all that.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You know what I think, Cleve Jones?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: That you're gonna get somewhere if you keep talking?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No. That you need to do what you're good at. Be a prick. Fight City Hall. Fight the cops. Fight the people who made you come here to do what you do.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Sorry old man, I'm leaving for Spain tomorrow. Europe. Got all the cash I need in my back pocket. A GROUP OF CLEVE'S FRIENDS shout at him to join them. Har watches him dart across the street to his friends.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn't come out until very late in life. There was nobody to--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: --look up to, no hope for a better life. Those that did were outcast... arrested.. suicide. And the young ones, who did escape home... and who arrive in San Francisco, and then what...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: PARAMEDICS placing a BLOODY VICTIM into a BODY

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: The ГўВЂВњfruitГўВЂВќ was walking home with his ГўВЂВњtrickГўВЂВќ when they were jumped. REVEAL: Harvey picks a blood stained whistle up off the street, the man's last attempt to call for help.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (from the victim's wallet) Name's Robert Hillsborough. Did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: He used to come into my shop. Are there any witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Just the "trick." Jerry Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Jerry wasn't a trick. They were lovers.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Call it what you will. He's our only witness and he says he can't identify the attackers.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: There'd be a dozen witnesses if they thought you boys had any real interest in keeping them safe.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You're the Mayor of Castro Street now, right Harvey? You really wanna help? Get your people to show some discretion on the streets, huh? HARVEY'S POV: The PARAMEDICS pull up the zipper on the bo bag. We follow the zipper past the victim's bloody hands, torso, his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TO HAND DURING THE FOLLOWING POLITICAL MEETING. (We catch glimpse of the PHOTOS and see naked skin).

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like the big guns and the rich gays in San Francisco are going to back Dianne Feinstein and other straight candidates they consider "gay-friendly."

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Who cares about those old queens? Scott is laying down on THE BIG RED COUCH.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Why isn't my campaign manager leading the meeting?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I'm beat, Harvey. I passed out flyers for seven hours straight.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: In the bathhouse?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (giving it right back) People in bathhouses vote. I'm tired. I'm taking a nap. Scott heads up the stairs to their apartment. A CUSTOMER comes in. Danny quickly gathers the REVEALING PHOTOS and puts them back in the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Just checking the exposure. That a new boyfriend? He's very cute.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: (taking the photos, embarrassed) Um... Thanks, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (to Jim) So who are these so-called "gay leaders?" And who appointed them? And what are you suggesting, Jim, that I'm supposed to go and solicit their endorsement? PAST HARVEY WE SEE A GRANDMOTHERLY VOLUNTEER, THELMA, ope the mail, casually reading a letter, then rising and approaching Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We're down here, on the streets, trying to help people, so where they hell are they?

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: David Goodstein is the publisher of The Advocate and he has a house--

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: A mansion--

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: --in Atherton.

dialogues.speaker: THELMA
dialogues.text: (clearly shaken) Harvey, you should read this. CLOSE ON THE LETTER as it goes from Thelma to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott reads the LETTER. Harvey sits VERY STILL.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: "Harvey Milk will have a dream journey and nightmare to hell, a night of horror. You will be stabbed and have your genitals, cock, balls, prick cut off." (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling the police.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: They probably wrote it. (off Scott's anxiety) Hey, If somebody tries to kill me, I'll get the sympathy vote, right? Could be just the push we need.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: You think this is funny? Look at it. Reluctantly, Harvey takes the letter from Scott.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It's a complete joke. No rhythm. No humor. It's insulting. CLOSE ON THE LETTER: Someone has drawn a STICK FIGURE of Harvey being tortured - bullets, knives, fire, etc. Harve makes a DECISION: He sticks the DRAWING to the refrigerat the first thing he'll see in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If you put it away, hide it in a drawer, it'll just get bigger and scarier. Now it's there. We'll see it every day. It can't get us.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: All this energy... to make yourself a target. And what for? Something we have no chance to win. Harvey wraps his arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I keep telling you, it's not just about winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, in his work boots and jeans, watches as a LARGE G SLIDES OPEN allowing his entry. Scott, even scruffier loo than Harvey, stands next to him.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The "top gays" in San Francisco were David Goodstein and his lawyer sidekick Rick Stokes. David was a (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: rich old queen who'd bought the biggest gay magazine, The Advocate. He had it delivered to subscribers in brown paper bags so no-one would know... That's how he lived his life, covered up, discreet. Harvey and Scott are shown to the pool area by a HOUSE BO Statues and potted plants and expensive marble. Everythin shouts "GOOD TASTE!" Scott strips off his clothes and DIVES INTO THE POOL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey has lunch with the "gay establishment": DAVID GOODSTEIN, 58, gold and turquoise jewelry, and Goodstein' protГѓВ©gГѓВ©, RICK STOKES, 45, reserved. Rick can't keep his eyes off naked Scott in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: I worked for a financial institution. I was very discreet. But someone spotted me at the opera, sitting in a box, next to my lover. And I was fired. That's when I decided to do something. So I bought The Advocate. And I use my money and my influence in quiet ways, to do what I can...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Endorsing straight candidates is what you think is best to help us?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: Yes, if they're friendly to our cause.

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: (DEFENSIVE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Politics is complicated in San Francisco, and Supervisor is a citywide office. Political alliances need to be built. You can't simply move here from across the country and run for office.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: But I am running for office. I'm on the ballot. I have the union rank and file, the seniors, and I could use your magazine's endorsement.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: Harvey, we're like the Catholic church. We welcome converts, but we don't make them Pope the same day.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And why haven't you run?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: It's too early for a gay candidate for Supervisor. Especially one from the Castro. It's bad for the community's image. Scott climbs out of the pool and sits at the table, naked sopping wet.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the Castro?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: Nobody works there. It's all sex and drugs and more sex and no one taking responsibility for their own problems.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The cops come into our neighborhood and beat us. They turn a blind eye if one of us is murdered.

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: Then we file a lawsuit against the city. We go to our political allies in City Hall...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: There are no real gay allies. Yes, our friends may sense our struggle, but they can't feel it. It's not life or death for them. We need our own in office.

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: You can't demand acceptance overnight.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Why not? How can we ask them to respect us if we don't show ourselves some self respect, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: The more ГўВЂВњoutГўВЂВќ you make us, the more you incite them. Step back and quiet down.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Go back into the closet? Is that what you're saying? Because I know the closet. I lived in it for more years than I care to remember. (rising to go) I don't need your endorsement. I'm not asking anyone for acceptance. I don't have time to ask.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: For you, politics is a game, a lark. Like putting on a rock festival or staging a "love-in." You're too old to be a hippie, Harvey Milk! Harvey turns around, ready for a fight.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm not a candidate, I'm part of a movement. The movement is the candidate. There's a difference. You don't see the difference. But I do.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (getting Harvey out) Thanks for the swim. I'm sorry I pissed in your pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SLOW MOTION MONTAGE OF: the citizens of the Castro are turning out to vote. Young, old, gay, straight... but a weight hangs over the day.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When the vote came in on election day... out of 32 candidates vying for 6 seats... We came in 10th. Just a handful short of being the first big eared, gay as a three- dollar-bill, cock sucker ever elected to public office.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: So... I went for it again in '75... with just a few... minor... adjustments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Harvey looking through a hole in the bottom of pair of well worn wing-tips. He tries them on anyhow. JUMP TO: Harvey steps out of a dressing room in a brown s His hair is cut short, his face is shaven clean. It's qui transformation. Scott and the old owner, LILY, size him u

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: No. Not cute. The shoes are hideous and I hate your hair. You're not fooling anybody.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna let the Pacific Heights biddies write me off again because of a ponytail. I like it. Scott is horrified. Harvey pulls a pair of movie ticket s from its inner pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cabaret? For two? Lily, is this from one of my kind?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, no. You won't run into the owner. He died in that suit.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: This isn't sexy, Harvey. Harvey grabs Scott, kisses him. Then playful:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Too bad. No more pot, no more bath houses for me and little poo.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CASTRO CAMERA
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: More ACTIVITY inside and outside the shop. More VOLUNTEERS. The printing press burns through flyers.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We ran and we lost the Supervisors race a second time in '75, but with (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: more votes than ever. So in 1976, against everyone's advice, I really pissed off the Democratic political power houses, because I ran against "their boy"--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --Art Agnos, a part of their "Political Machine." And this time we weren't running for City Supervisor. This time it was bigger, California State Assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a firestorm of words as Harvey debates Art Agnos.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It's a racket. It's 1976 and you still have to be straight, white, Catholic and male to get into the San Francisco police force. It's Racist. Homophobic.

dialogues.speaker: ART AGNOS
dialogues.text: How many people do you consider enemies, Harvey? I've counted five already. Art smiles. Chuckles flutter through the audience.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You're right, Art. And many are your closest friends. You see, I don't think State Assembly seats should be awarded on the basis of service to the Democrat Machine. Machines operate on oil and grease. They're dirty, dehumanizing, and too often unresponsive to any needs but those of the operator.

dialogues.speaker: ART AGNOS
dialogues.text: Mr. Milk, I've worked for years as a social worker in this city. I know Sacramento. I know how to get done what we all need done there.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Tell me Mr. Agnos... right here in the Castro, Robert Hillsbourough was murdered for walking home with his long time partner. Stabbed, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: fifteen times. The last words he heard were "Faggot, Faggot, Faggot..." And you say you're outraged, but why won't your liberal establishment return our calls? Why won't they bring these murderers to justice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art Agnos puts his arm around Harvey as they walk out.

dialogues.speaker: ART AGNOS
dialogues.text: You know Harv', your whole rap's a real downer.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: My God, you're handsome up close. I can't tell you how much I'm looking forward to licking you... in the polls.

dialogues.speaker: ART AGNOS
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk a lot about what you're against. What are you for? In this town, you gotta give em' a reason for optimism or you're cooked. Art gets into his car and goes. Harvey has no car. He sto and PONDERS ART'S WORDS... They stick with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott tries to make a simple meal of pasta, struggling to operate in the kitchen that is filled with Harvey's POLIT ENTOURAGE and VOLUNTEERS. He finds Harvey, Jim, and Dick having an impromptu strate meeting in the adjoining bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey. Dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: ... get some union boys in the audience, they love me...

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: I can't control who's in the audience...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey, you need to eat something. Now.
Scott steps back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen. Our apartment is officially off limits. CHASES the VOLUNTEERS out of the kitchen, out of his bedroom... down the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Downstairs. Time to go. Go. OUT! Harvey emerges, about to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't say anything. For once, Harvey keeps his mouth shut. Jim and Dick sneak past Scott, sheepishly. When Scott and Harvey are alone..

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit down and eat. Harvey and Scott eat dinner in tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: If you say one thing about politics or your campaign or where you're speaking tonight or whose endorsement you need... I'll stab you with my fork I swear to God.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say... This is the most delicious meal I've ever eaten in my entire life. Harvey gives a warm smile. Scott gives a laugh, but he lo like he's about to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If we lose this one, it'll be just me and you again. I promise. Scott nods. That's exactly what he needed to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks Castro's streets alone, toward his apartment

A CAR PULLS UP BEHIND HARVEY. A MAN jumps out of the car, the driver speeds around the block. Harvey turns a corner The man follows. Harvey picks up his pace. He searches hi pockets for a whistle, a weapon, and beelines it to his s his nerves are failing him. He gets to the doorway of his camera store, and runs face first into: CLEVE JONES. He's not the feisty young kid he on the street earlier. He's been sitting on Harvey's step waiting with wet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Phoenix? (off Cleve's smile) We should go inside. They do. Harvey locks the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey pours two cups of coffee, and delivers one to Clev who is pulled away on the big red couch.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: You staying up with me?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The election's tomorrow. I won't sleep... Was he good looking?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: No. He was hideous.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hard to tell what's worse. With me, my boyfriends usually find better looking ones to cheat with.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I thought we were gonna spend the rest of our lives together.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Guess what, Cleve Jones.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You're going to meet the most extraordinary men, the sexiest, brightest, funniest men, and you're going to fall in love with so many of them, and you won't know until (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the end of your life who your greatest friends were or your greatest love was.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Is that supposed to help?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Maybe a little. Or not.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I went to Spain last month... long story. In Barcelona, there was this memorial march for gay people who died under Franco. The police tried to break it up. It started a riot. A bullet ripped through a drag queens scalp, his wig flew off, but he kept fighting. There was blood literally running in the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We could have a revolution here too. But you can't just use the Castro to cruise. You gotta fight.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: You think you'll win?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Winning isn't my strong suit.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (BRAVADO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't "do" losing. Ever. Maybe I should run for office, and you can work for me. (off Harvey's laugh) If you can do it, I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Can you assemble a thousand people in an hour?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: All right, if I run again, you're my man.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Polls open in 3 hours. Lets hit the bus stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is on the back of a motorcycle. The driver heads u Market Street. Folks stand in voting lines, flags outside polling places. City Hall's tall dome grows nearer.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And we lost that Assembly Race too, which made me a bona fide three- time, political loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE TV SET PLAYING A 1970's ORANGE JUICE COMMERC featuring runner up to Miss America, ANITA BRYANT.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA BRYANT, (SINGING ON TV)
dialogues.text: "Come to the Florida sunshine tree, great tasting orange juice naturally, orange juice with lots of vitamin c, from the Florida sunshine tree." Harvey is alone in the shop, surrounded by remnants of a celebration party that never happened. Jim Rivaldo lets himself into the store. Jim has his maps rolled up under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: (trying to cheer up Harvey) We lost, but we lost by less! More votes than ever... (Harvey fake grins) I remember when that used to work. I want to show you something. This is remarkable. Jim starts laying out his trusty MAPS, color coded with precinct results from that night.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The red is where you did best tonight. If we can get the initiative on district elections to pass, and we can -- we can -- our new Supervisor's District will go right up Market. Right around the Castro.
The district Jim outlines is ALL BRIGHT RED.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you run for Supervisor with this new district, it's a potential landslide. You'll be the first up- front gay man elected to major office in the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I don't know if I have another one in me. Or Scott. But Harvey's gaze deceives his words. HOLD ON HARVEY - contemplating a FOURTH run for office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GROUP gathers around the TV WHICH SHOWS NATIONWIDE NE CLIPS OF ANITA BRYANT celebrating her election victory in Florida (overturning a pro-gay statute). A CHYRON READS: "Landslide defeat for Florida Gay Rights Law."

dialogues.speaker: ANITA BRYANT, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Tonight the laws of God and the cultural values of man have been vindicated. The people of Dade county, the normal majority, have said enough, enough, enough.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: Gays in Florida can now be removed from their jobs and prosecuted if their "deviant" lifestyles are uncovered. HARVEY'S POV OUT A WINDOW: FURIOUS GAYS pour out of the b BLOWING WHISTLES, raising TRASH CANS... It might turn int RIOT.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA BRYANT, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Gays can't reproduce, so they must recruit young people into their lifestyle...

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: Bryant, a spokeswoman for the orange juice industry, vowed to (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: bring her campaign to the rest of the country... Harvey's PHONE RINGS. He snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Scottie?

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir. I um... I read about you in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I can't talk right--

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sir, I think I want to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No. You don't want to do that. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: In Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You saw me in a paper in Minnesota? How'd I look?

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: My folks are taking me to this place tomorrow. A hospital. To fix me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with you. Listen to me. You don't have to hurt yourself, okay? Are you there? (only breathing from the other end) Here's what you have to do. Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Get on a bus. Go to the next biggest city. New York, San Francisco, LA, or even Minneapolis. It doesn't matter. Just leave. (off the boy's tears) You won't be alone. There are people out here just like you who will welcome you and love you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're not sick. You're not wrong. God does not hate you. Just leave.

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Yes. You can. Just get on a bus.

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I can't... I can't walk, sir. I'm in a wheelchair... Sir. Are you there? Harvey FORCES HIMSELF TO SOUND CALM...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: That's okay. It's going to be okay. Over the phone, Harvey hears the SOUND OF AN ADULT VOICE, someone finding the BOY on the phone, then... The LINE goes DEAD. It's all too much for Harvey. There's nothing a speech or a pep talk can do to fix this. Harvey overwhelmed. Dick comes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: Harvey, you better come down. There's gonna be a riot. Moving in a daze, stunned by the call, Harvey digs out A BULLHORN and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside, SCOTT WATCHES HIS LOVER JUMPING BACK IN THE FREY. A weight hangs. He doesn't follow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleve RUSHES into the bar (ON FIRE WITH RIGHTEOUS FURY) a BLOWS A POLICE WHISTLE to get everyone's attention.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Out of the bar and into the streets! Anita Bryant is coming after you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry young men mill around the streets, their rage build Someone TOSSES a trash can and it ROLLS. A POLICEMAN in riot gear comes up to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: If you can't control em', we will.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Give me permission to march them.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by the massive crowd, HARVEY CLIMBS THE LARGE that covers the subway construction at Market and Castro. It's a stage of sorts. Harvey lifts his bullhorn to his l

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I know you are angry. I am angry. Follow me through the streets of San Francisco to share our anger! Harvey jumps down and begins walking, not sure if the mob will follow. Finally, they do. Cleve catches up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are they following in back?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Yes. Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I don't know. (off Cleve's concern) We have to keep them moving. Exhaust them. March them till they drop. We can't have a riot tonight. Harvey LIFTS THE BULLHORN. He starts a marching chant. Th crowd starts following along. JUMP TO: Gays glare at cops. Cops beat their nightsticks against their chests and power poles. Anger burns as Harv marches the mob toward City Hall. Dick and Jim catch up.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: They're still too hot in back. They'll burn the joint down.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Help me turn them up Van Ness. We'll go all the way to Broadway.
Dick heads back to try and wrangle the crowd. Harvey continues marching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey arrives, the crowd still hot. Cops beat their nightsticks against their shields. Some jab protesters, trying to incite a fight. Anger burns. Harvey climbs the steps, his stage. He lifts his bullhorn

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: My name is Harvey Milk... And I want to recruit you. The CROWD ROARS APPROVAL.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am here tonight to say, we will no longer sit quietly in our closets. We must fight. Not just in the Castro, or San Francisco, but everywhere the Anitas go. Anita Bryant did not win tonight. Anita Bryant has brought us together... She is going to create a national gay force! (The crowd ROARS) And the young people in Richmond, Minnesota, or Jackson, Mississippi, or Woodmere, New York... Who are coming out and hearing Anita Bryant on television telling them that they're wrong, they're sick, that there is no place for them in this great country, in this world... They're looking to us for something tonight... (his big moment, realizing his true mission) And I say, we have to give them hope! The CROWD goes WILD. HARVEY'S SPEECH CROSSES THE CUT TO..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey speaks to the "PARENT-TEACHERS UNITED FOR BETTER SCHOOLS" group.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --Hope for a better world... Hope for a better tomorrow... Hope for a (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: better place to come to if the pressures at home are too great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey speaks to a hall filled with TEAMSTERS.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hope for the worker who awakens from the American dream to find that all the jobs have left the country... We gotta give em' HOPE! PAN FACES OF TEAMSTERS - Several MINORITY FACES. CLOSE ON

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap, an intimate tone) When San Francisco changed the voting rules--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is still speaking into the tape recorder...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: --they allowed people to elect Supervisors directly from their own neighborhoods. A black neighborhood could elect an African- American. Chinatown could elect a Chinese Supervisor... And the Castro could choose me or Rick Stokes. But decent art begs for balance, right? So little district 8, two miles south of The Castro--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES ALONG THE STREET catching glimpses of church shops and tidy houses.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --promised to stay the same as ever. Conservative, Irish, Catholic and with just the right touch of poetry, they found themselves a handsome ex-cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAN WHITE holds a small press conference. His words are fiery, but his delivery and stage presence are lacking.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I'm not going to be forced out of San Francisco by splinter groups of social radicals, social deviants, and incorrigibles. You must realize there are thousands upon thousands of frustrated, angry people such as yourselves waiting to unleash a fury that will eradicate the malignancies which blight our beautiful city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's suit is laid out. A record turns. Wagner blasts the windows. Scott is folding his clothes into a box.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Evelyn Lear's in town, at the Opera house in Tannhauser.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What if she strolls into the Castro for a cocktail? (Scott keeps packing) Just one more. We can't let Rick Stokes take it.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Let Rick have it. Nobody thinks you're a fraud here, Harvey. You're not in New York, you're not a closet case asshole anymore. People respect you here. Relax for a year. Get us back on our feet.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If people are ever going to take me seriously, I have to win this one.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Since when did you care if anyone took you seriously?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Anita wants to put us all back in concentration camps. Rick Stokes is too weak to beat her back if she gets to California. I have to be in office to protect us from them.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I can't do another one. (Harvey says nothing) I'll be back for my sheets. If you're not here, I'll see you in the shop next week. Scott picks up his box of clothes and starts out of the apartment. Harvey, not meaning a word:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If you leave me right now... I can find someone new.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I know. You're a catch. Scott leaves. Harvey is in shock, unable to comprehend th loss. Unable/unwilling to reverse the choice he's made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENTOURAGE is completely caught up in the new campaign (Cleve, Jim, Dick, and newcomer MICHAEL WONG, 23, asexual devoutly political). Harvey is RANTING, ripping down an Assembly campaign poster.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: --Ring out the old, ring in the new. This is over. Done. I don't want to see anything that say's fucking Assembly. This three-time loser faggot is running for Supervisor goddamn it! ANNE KRONENBERG, 23, parks her motorcycle outside, WALKS THE CAMERA SHOP, and plants herself behind HARVEY'S DESK. Cleve, Mike, Jim and Dick are STARING at Anne.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: Who the heck is she?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (suddenly cool) Our new campaign manager. She called last week to volunteer and I asked her to help.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: Help or take over? What about Scott?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We need new blood. (introducing them) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guys... Anne Kronenberg. (Off their puzzled looks) She's a woman... A woman who likes women. Odd, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Hi guys. Mr. Milk... Rick Stokes isn't pulling out. He's officially filed to run against you. My friend at The Advocate says David Goodstein is backing him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: A gay candidate against a gay candidate. It's unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: They'll split the gay vote. The straights will divide and conquer.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Try to find out when they're going to announce.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: You replaced Scott with a lesbian?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Anne worked on a recycling campaign up North. She's very organized.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: How do you know she's not a plant from Rick Stokes' campaign?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Are you guys always this paranoid?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: Yes. They take after Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be doing someone's laundry?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: Right after you redecorate my house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: (pointed at Jim Rivaldo) Sir, my girlfriends say you guys don't like women. Just asking, is there a place for us in all this, or are you scared of girls?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Gentleman, we already have a tinker bell, a lotus-blossom, Jim and Dick in your three-piece suits. We need someone to manage things. A woman this time. She's the right price, and she has bigger balls than any of you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Just give me whatever's left over in the register at the end of the day. So should I call the Chronicle about getting US an endorsement? No? OFF the group of misfits, considering the addition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OFF: a large "RICK STOKES, SUPERVISOR DISTRICT 5" pos to reveal Anne Kronenberg outside the hall handing "MILK" signs to a long line of gathering women and lesbians who filing in. Flanked by a PEEVED AID, Rick Stokes rushes out of the lecture hall and confronts Anne.

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: Young lady, you must be confused. This is my night, not Mr. Milk's.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: (as pleasant as can be) No, sir. I'm Harvey's new campaign manager. Anne Kronenberg.

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: Then you should know this race is for District 5, the Castro, not for all of your lesbian... compadres-- A tough lesbian kisses Anne and stares Rick down as she h in. Rick looks uncomfortable around all these women.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Are we distracting you, Mr. Stokes? I'd hate to screw you up on your big night. Dick runs up looking for more fliers. Taking Rick even mo off his game, Dick is flirtatious.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: Hi Rick, handsome suit. Annie, do you have any more hand cards?

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: These people are not from this area. They need to leave. Now.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: Not true. Guess where we found them all, Rick? A slew of them. Way up on Valencia Street. Living right there in our district. And you see, as it turns out, Annie here is very, very popular with the ladies. Dick puts his arm around Anne. Rick is stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of supporters hold "MILK for Supervisor" signs in long line along Market St. waving to commuters. Anne walk the long line, handing out new signs to arriving voluntee Harvey is handing out FLYERS. He is exhausted, his throat RAW. The campaign is nearly over. A WEIRD MOMENT: A BOY walks up to Harvey and hands him a flier. ALL SOUND GOES DEAD ON THE SOUNDTRACK as HARVEY'S lock into the BOY'S EYES. Harvey reads the FLIER: ГўВЂВњUnite and Fight for Dan Whi Harvey looks back to pat the BOY'S head, but he's gone. H looks to the sidewalk for the kid... a parent... nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is still looking at the flier. Anne is leaving wit stack of SF Chronicles. Cleve comes in, pulls one off her stack, and looks for "the article."

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: They've accused me of many things, but never as blatant a lie as this.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: First ever newspaper endorsement.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (reading the article) They endorsed you for being a good businessman? Has Scott read this? He'll piss himself.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Go show him. (Cleve starts to go) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cleve, maybe you should go find a boy to celebrate with. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I'm going to The Stud. Meet me out. Cleve goes. His energy is boundless. Harvey sits alone watching the bargoers return home through his front windo bitter-sweetness lingers. A couple waves, one shouts out:

dialogues.speaker: GAY MAN
dialogues.text: Gonna win this time, Milk? They walk on, not waiting for an answer. Then, a drunk, cute, Latino, JACK LIRA, 25, stops. He sta in at the political ads in the window. Harvey watches him sway drunk out of his mind, waiting for him to fall. The make eye contact. Harvey smiles. Jack tries to. Harvey pi up a folding chair and walks it out to him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: (re: poster in the window) You're more handsome in the posters.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Thank you. Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: (too drunk to hear, flirting) ...Palomino's are my favorite horse. They're smart. They're fast and compact. Do you think I'm more like a Palomino or a Stallion? Jack smiles, out of his mind. Then he sits/falls down int the chair, and slides off. Harvey stands above the passed young man. A newcomer. A wounded bird. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely nude, Jack plays a tantalizing game of seducti allowing Harvey to hold him, then wriggling away... Danci against Harvey then BITING his shoulder... LYING on the b then ROLLING away when Harvey tries to hold him... No TALK. No POLITICS. Just SEX. A perfect RELEASE for Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey holds Jack after lovemaking.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: My father beat me when he found out... So I came here. I stay in this man's house. But I don't like him.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Shh, it's okay, now. No one's ever going to beat you again. A long, comforting beat between them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (smiles, playful) Do you even remember my name? (a beat, Jack shakes his head, he can't remember) Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: I love you, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY stands in a voting booth. He goes down the list of names. He finally punches the one next to "HARVEY MILK" District 5, and pulls the lever. The chads fall.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And for the first time in my life, it all came together... the union boys, the women, the seniors, the minorities... All of the us's showed up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV lights blast Castro Camera. A raucous crowd pours into streets to greet the roar of motorcycles. Anne pulls up w the Sheriff on back. Harvey is passenger on a second bike HARVEY IS VICTORIOUS! He is instantly swarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shop is packed. It's a giant celebration party. Anne Cleve are working the door. SCOTT SMITH WATCHES FROM THE CROWD OUTSIDE THE SHOP as Rick Stokes and David Goodstein to get in.

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: We just want to congratulate him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. We're all full.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: (seeing Harvey inside) Harvey! Harvey!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It's too crowded. Sorry! JACK LIRA shoves his way toward the door...

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: Harvey! Harvey PULLS JACK INSIDE, right past Goodstein and Stokes Harvey CATCHES A GLIMPSE OF SCOTT OUTSIDE...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Scottie--? But Scott fades into the CROWD. Harvey (with Jack at his side) is pulled back into the party.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (eyeing Jack skeptically) The new Mrs. Milk. I give it a week.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: (the crowd) Harvey, is this all for you? Are you this famous?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No, darling. We do this all the time. Do you like it? Jim is calling out NAMES of the OTHER WINNERS.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: Carol Ruth Silver... Gordon Lau... It's the most liberal Board in years!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What about Dan White? Did he win?

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: (YES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll deal with him tomorrow. Harvey is DOUSED with champagne.
JUMP TO: Harvey is interviewed by a TV REPORTER. Jack squeezes his way under Harvey's arm and into the picture.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNEL 5 REPORTER
dialogues.text: Does this mean, as many straights are concerned, maybe the gays are taking over San Francisco? Are you going to be a Supervisor for all the people?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I have to be. That's what I was elected for. I have to be there to open up the dialogue for the sensitivities of all people, all their problems, the problems that effect this city effect all of us. (toasts the camera) Thank you San Francisco! Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: SET TO MUSIC: In his old brown suit, Harvey walks to City Hall with a crowd of supporters. The familiar faces now include Jack Lira.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On City Hall's steps, Mayor Moscone swears in HARVEY.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I, Harvey Milk, do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of California against all enemies, foreign and domestic; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter and during such time as I hold the office of Supervisor, City and County of San Francisco. Bulbs FLASH. A light rain begins to fall. Umbrellas go up

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anita Bryant said gay people brought the drought to California. Looks to me like it's finally started raining! Cheers. Harvey is emboldened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off a TV in Scott's NEW APARTMENT, we see a S.F. Morning featuring new Supervisors, Harvey Milk and Dan White.

dialogues.speaker: HOST, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: This will be the first time in many years that we've seen so many new faces on the Board of Supervisors. Do you think such diversity will cripple the Board?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The name of the game on the Board is six votes to get anything passed. So, like it or not, Dan and I are now in bed together... politically speaking. THE CAMERA REVEALS SCOTT watching the program. He's been all night.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I've assured Harvey here that my brochure's comments about "social deviants" referred more to junkies than to his people. See, I'm about to have my first child. I have to make sure this city remains a decent place to raise him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The segment over, sound assistants help Harvey and Dan re their microphones. Harvey tries to draw Dan in:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: How long were you a fireman, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: A couple of years.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And before that... You were a police officer? Dan studies Harvey suspiciously... What's his point?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You have something against cops?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No. They tend to have something against me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (seeing Dan react uncomfortably) But firefighters. Now those are true heroes... They supported me in the last campaign. I support them fully.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I meant what I said. I'd like to work together. Dan hesitantly accepts Harvey's handshake. It's a step.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: (cracking a smile) I'll see you at the office, Mr. Milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey goes through the metal detectors at the entrance a finds Cleve in a NEW SUIT waiting for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What do you think of my new theater?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: A bit over the top.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What's with the suit?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I got it from a friend. Harvey leads Cleve from the elevator to the grand stairca

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: When you come here, I want you to wear the tightest jeans possible. Never blend in. And no elevators. Ever. Always take the stairs, you can make such a grand entrance going up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey leads Cleve down the hall of Supervisors' offices, passing Dianne Feinstein's open door.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And street talk only around Feinstein. Shit, goddamn, fuck, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: all that. It bugs the hell out of her. They arrive at his Lead Aide's desk: it's Anne Kronenberg

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Morning Annie, let's set Cleve up on mail.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Will do.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Come into my office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks in. Michael and Jim are in a strategy sessio

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The first order of business that will come out of this office is a city wide Gay Rights Ordinance. Just like the one Anita shot down in Dade County. What do you think, Lotus Blossom?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: I think it's good. Not great.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Then make it brilliant. I want Anita's attention here. In San Francisco. I want her to bring her fight to US... This Bill needs a unanimous vote. We need headlines.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: Dan White won't vote for this. Harvey puts his fingers to his lips and points down the h indicating Dan is down there. Harvey whispers:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Dan's fine. He's just uneducated. We can teach him. Dan pops his head into Harvey's office.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Harvey, committee meets at 9:30. Oh, hi Michael, Jim. (to Harvey) Hey, did you get the invitation to (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: my son's christening? I invited a few of the other supes as well.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Great! All smiles, Dan leaves. Cleve mocks him. OFF Mike Wong's expression: THAT WAS BIZARRE.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Are you going?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hey. I'll let him christen me, if he'll vote for my Gay Rights Ordinance. We need allies. We need everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood is booming. Storefronts and sidewalks filled. This is not the rundown Castro that Harvey moved into 3 years ago. Harvey heads home, greeted by his PROUD CONSTITUENTS. He stops at the CAMERA SHOP when he notices a BROKEN WIND near the side entrance to his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey RUSHES UP THE STAIRS into his apartment and finds: JACK LIRA - Lighting a candle on the table which has been for a lovely, romantic dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: Welcome home, Harvey! I hope you're hungry. I only know how to cook one thing, but I make it good.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Did you... break in?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: I asked the boy downstairs to let me in...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Danny?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
