dialogues.text: He wouldn't let me in. So I came in this way. Your friends aren't very nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (avoiding the fight) I have a Town Hall meeting tonight, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: You work too hard. I'm sorry about your window. I'll fix it tomorrow. (turning on the charm) Are you surprised?!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Jack, I have to go. I have an invitation to a party tomorrow. Lots of rich people, politicians. We could get all dressed up... Jack turns up the music, takes Harvey's hands and guides through a simple dance.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: So I could be the first lady?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: I watched TV here today. All day. I saw All My Children. They killed Margo. I knew it was going to happen. They try and trick you but it never works.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (enjoying this) You always see it coming?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: What? Killing the blonde? Every time. I'm good with that. (gets slow, sensual) I think now the old lady is going to have an affair. Then she'll get killed or married. Always one or the other. Dead or married. Jack starts dancing with Harvey again. It's sweet, intima

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If I make you a key, you won't break my windows again, right?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: That's right. The dance lesson is a lovely distraction. Harvey won't be going back to work tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey watches water pour over an INFANT BOY. He tries ha to feel comfortable, but he's the only Jew, and likely th only gay man at Dan's child's baptism. Dan looks to Harvey, the proud father. Harvey waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey and Dan have pulled themselves away.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm proposing a citywide ordinance. It ensures that a person who already has a job can't be fired for their orientation.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure my constituents would favor that. Dan looks over to his WIFE and NEWBORN SON.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Is anyone else here from the Board?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You're the only one who showed up I think.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Were you christened here?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Yes. Right here. Same Parish. My grandma immigrated here when this was an Irish Catholic city. The City of St. Francis... A lot's changed here since then.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You're more like one of us now... an outsider.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You're not like most homosexuals, are you, Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Do you know a lot of "homosexuals?"

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: (smiles, then) Say, where do you stand on the Psychiatric Center the City's been pushing into my district?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well, I'd have to study it...

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Getting it out of my district was a key piece of my platform. It only attracts arsonist, rapists, all that, you know.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. A campaign promise.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: A big one. (QUIET)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say we watch out for each other's interests? I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'd like that, too, Dan. Mary Ann White approaches with their child. It's awkward, if she's walked in on something intimate.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Slipped into some shop talk.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The Gay Rights Ordinance. My fault.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ANN WHITE
dialogues.text: Seems an inappropriate subject in here don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hey, don't knock it till you've tried it. His attempt to break the tension goes down in flames. She cracks a polite smile. They're from very different worlds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is under pressure from his own advisors (Michael, Dick, Cleve) to vote against Dan's bill.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: Supervisors Silver and Lau are asking you to vote to keep this Psychiatric Center in Dan's district. It'll go down 6 to 5 if you vote to get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: It's a Youth Campus, Harvey. These are kids that would be displaced from their families if it's moved.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I can't just dump Dan. The guy's got nothing going for him. No friends...

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Here we go, Harvey to the rescue. Isn't it enough we have to put up with Jack?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Lay off. He registered 120 voters last week.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: So do any of your volunteers, but you don't make them all first lady.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: What does Dan White do for you? Really? Politically?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: He intrigues me... I think he may be one of us. Everyone groans. Cleve camps it up:

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Dear God, say it ain't so!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It's just a theory...

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: You just think he's cute.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No... I know what it's like to live that life. That lie. You can see it in Dan's eyes... The fear, the pressure... Anne Kronenberg walks in. She's got that look in her eyes Something's up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good or Bad?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Not great. State Senator John Briggs is Anita Bryant's go-to guy in California for sure. He's filed his petition for a statewide referendum to fire all gay teachers and anyone who supports them. A pall falls over the room. This is worse than expected.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: How many signatures will he need to qualify for the ballot?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Whatever. He can get them in two Sundays at church in Orange County.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (instead of fear, excitement bubbles up) This means the fight's coming here, where we can do something about it! Wichita's one thing, Kansas City. But Anita's heading for San Francisco! She's not going to know what hit her. Smile, children! This is the fight we've been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CA State Senator, JOHN BRIGGS, 47, delivers his message t the PRESS, THE TV CREWS, AND A MASS OF PROTESTERS. HARVEY AND HIS GROUP are amongst the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: My proposition promises to protect our children from these gay perverts and pedophiles who recruit our children to their deviant lifestyles, including the ones who (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: do it in our public schools. It's time to root them out. In the crowd is teacher TOM AMMIANO, 36, colorful, worked

dialogues.speaker: TOM AMMIANO
dialogues.text: And how are you going to determine who's a homosexual?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: Sir, my bill outlines procedures for identifying homosexuals.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PROTESTER
dialogues.text: How? Will you be sucking them off?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: Sir, you can argue with me, but you cannot argue with God. It's getting ugly fast. Briggs is whisked away by TWO OFFICERS. He trips off the curb and is quickly scooped up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan's house is filled with RELATIVES for a birthday celebration. Dan is glued to the NEWS, watching BRIGGS. Dan's RELATIVES gather around the TV. Mary Ann puts their BABY into Dan's arms and returns to wrangling kids.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Look what happened in Germany. Now Anita Bryant already says that Jews and Muslims are going to hell, you know she's got a shopping list. We are not going to let John Briggs or Anita Bryant legislate bigotry in this city... Hold on Dan watching Harvey on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleve and Anne sit in the entry way, Cleve in his tight j and shirt. He's very out of place amongst all the suits. Harvey walks in. Cleve and Anne rush to his side. David Goodstein and Rick Stokes turn to greet Milk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: Hello, Harvey. Running late? (Harvey doesn't stop) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Harvey... your boyfriend is in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Excuse me, David?

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: (QUIETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Latino, he's locked himself in the coat room... Mr. Milk, Phil Burton is here. He's likely the next Speaker of the House and a much needed ally against Prop Six. We don't need a scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is at the door. Jack is locked inside the room.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You're right, I know, I was late by twenty minutes. I'm sorry, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Who were you with? Scott? Some boy?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I was at work. Come out, sugar pea.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No. You embarrassed me. I didn't know anyone. These are not good people. I don't want to be here.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Then go home, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No. I'll wait for you. Go away. A tight smile from Harvey as he looks up to Cleve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, Cleve and a dozen others are scattered about the for a meeting with the DEMOCRATIC PARTY ESTABLISHMENT. U. Congressman PHIL BURTON, 51, leans on a desk, listening.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: The Briggs initiative is polling at 75 percent for approval statewide.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: 80 percent in other polls. Some even have us losing San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: (condescending to Cleve) So it's important we not deceive people into thinking we can beat this, or we'll have riots and only increase this backlash.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY JONES
dialogues.text: Good point, David. Let's just roll right over. Make it easier for Briggs to fuck us up the ass. Rick and David are horrified. Phil Burton rises above it, passing out copies of his new Anti-Briggs Initiative flie

dialogues.speaker: PHIL BURTON
dialogues.text: We're taking this very seriously in my office. We want to send one of these to every home in California. We'll need money to do that.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (reading the flier) "Proposition Six is an affront to Human Rights. An invasion of the State into the private lives of California citizens." (points to the pictures) Does it even say the word gay on this thing? Anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: No Harvey, purposefully not.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL BURTON
dialogues.text: With the heat bearing down on your movement right now, we think it's best to dodge the "gay" bullet. Go for the human rights angle.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: People need to know who's affected. This flier needs at least one old queen on it. (a dig, to Goodstein) Why don't you volunteer for that, David?

dialogues.speaker: RICK STOKES
dialogues.text: (an olive branch) Corey Wares is an out gay--

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: (cutting Rick him off)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: This is shit. Shit and masturbation. It's a coward's response to a dangerous threat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID GOODSTEIN
dialogues.text: (a beat, then) I think you should leave. In the face of Phil Burton, most the others seem to agree HARVEY PUTS PHIL BURTON'S FLYER IN THE FIREPLACE on his w out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey knocks on the coat check door.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Jack, it's time to go. (to Cleve) Get everyone together. I want young people, women, fresh heads. Fighters and organizers, not politicians.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (as if Jack can't spell) What about, S-C-O-T-T? OFF HARVEY, knowing Scott would be an asset. Jack opens t door and grabs Harvey's hand. They go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's clan is assembled (Jim, Dick, Mike, Cleve, Anne, Jack, Denis) along with fiery teacher Tom Amiano and MANY OTHER YOUNG ACTIVISTS. A HANDSOME PIZZA DELIVERY GUY is setting down boxes of pizzas. They're in for the night. The atmosphere is 180 degrees different from the previous stuffy meeting.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: We're not interested in working with those old Democratic Party shits. THE DOOR OPENS and someone new enters. He's HOLDING THE H OF... SCOTT SMITH. They are obviously a new couple.
Scott and his BOYFRIEND find a place on the floor. Harvey and Scott's EYES MEET across the room.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: But we can't afford infighting anymore, Cleve. We have to bring together every group. Even the old school Democrats.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (taking over) Is anybody gonna pay the pizza guy, or are we just gonna stare? People start chipping in for the HANDSOME PIZZA GUY.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we're gonna convince the 90% to give a shit about us 10%... We have to let 'em know who we are. (his big new idea) Everybody's coming out. The entire state. No matter where they live.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: "Come out, come out, wherever you are!"

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm serious. (beat, the room gets quiet) We're going to tell everyone in the state to come out. Every gay doctor, lawyer, teacher, dog catcher... We have to leave the ghetto, let all those people out there know that they do know one of us. And if people won't step out of the closet, we open the door for them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: The whole state is not San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Clearly, Scott.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: It could be dangerous. There is such a thing as a right to privacy.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Privacy's our enemy. You want real political power? Let's tell the truth for a change. Starting here. If there's anybody in this room, right now, who hasn't told their families, their friends, their employers... Do it. Now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: My folks know already. A beat. The room is silent. Dick looks ill.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: I haven't told my father yet...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (a beat, then) People vote two to one for us if they know just one of us. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleve, show Dick where you keep your phone.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: It's in the bedroom. After a moment, Dick RISES and follows Cleve out of the r People are stunned by Harvey's outrageous demand. Harvey Scott GLARING at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meeting is breaking up, and Scott lets his NEW BOYFRI go ahead. Harvey ducks away from Jack and intercepts Scot

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I thought you were done with politics.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Politics. Not the movement. What the hell was that in there?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: The movement needs people to be up- front. Why were you fighting me?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: You were the biggest closet case alive in New York. You told me and all your boyfriends to keep our (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: traps shut. You were the hypocrite in there.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: My parents are gone. My brother knows. I'm sure they knew.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I had to listen to your phone calls home to Mom. Hear you deny that I existed. You want to be "normal" as bad as any of us. More than any of us... Those are kids in there. You're asking them to lose their families.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If their families won't love them for who they are, who they really are, then they should lose them.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: That's fucking insane.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (re: Scott's new Boyfriend) Who's he? Do you live together?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Someone I'm seeing. He's good for me. He makes me stay home at nights, out of the bars...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (quietly, so Jack doesn't hear) I miss you.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, Harvey, don't... (eyeing Jack down the street) What's that about?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: (calling out) Har-veyyyyy!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: He needs me. Scott nods. THAT'S ALWAYS BEEN HARVEY'S ACHILLES HEAL. He walks away from Harvey, leaving him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne bangs her gavel like a mad woman. Harvey's adamant

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK DIANNE FEINSTEIN
dialogues.text: I have told no lies here Supervisor Milk, you will today or to Supervisor White come to order. in the past--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: --I want it noted that I never promised to back moving any Mental Health Centers. I greatly respect Supervisor White, but I would like his remarks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE FEINSTEIN
dialogues.text: Duly noted. We will take a recess before recording the vote. Fellow Supervisor, CAROL RUTH SILVER, leans over to Harve

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RUTH SILVER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Harvey. Harvey is preoccupied with Dan approaching. He leans back

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Can I have a moment with Harvey? Alone, please, Carol? She politely recognizes the tension and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you turning on me like this at the last minute? What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I didn't have all the details. I'll help you craft a different version that doesn't displace any kids.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Harvey, I can't go back to my family and to my folks and to my district without this. Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm getting a lot of pressure, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You strung me along. And now you're throwing me to the wolves.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You only need one more vote, Dan. There are 5 other Supervisors you could convince besides me. Dan grabs Harvey. It's threatening. A new side of Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I'll vote against your Queer Law. I'll get Quentin against it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It'll still pass. You can't keep alienating yourself here, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I gave you a chance, Harvey. I really did. You blew it. You really blew it. Dan goes, the rage of a scorned adolescent under his suit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's mood has darkened as he talks into his recorder.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Across the country, a handful of city councils had passed the very first ordinances protecting gay people against discrimination. But Anita Bryant and her right wing Christian fundamentalists were creating and exploiting and fanning a backlash. Now she had referenda to repeal all of these gay rights ordinances. While we were preparing for the battle against Briggs and Prop Six, Anita Bryant was taking her show on the road... sweeping the country. Her next stop was Wichita, Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHYRON: "Landslide: Wichita says NO to Gays." Anita talks a REPORTER. BRIGGS is among the supporters at her side.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA BRYANT
dialogues.text: I give thanks for all of our foot soldiers of God here in Wichita. But we must push on. Look what happened to Sodom and to the world of Noah. Onward Christian soldiers! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANITA BRYANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (lifting her hand with

dialogues.speaker: BRIGGS'S
dialogues.text: On to California!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A telephone tree MONTAGE starts with Cleve on a PAY PHONE Castro Street:

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Hi. We're losing Wichita. Rally tonight. Sundown. Market and Castro. A MULTIPLYING FRAME EFFECT: the person he called calls tw others, they call four, then more and more as the tree gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY'S POV ON: The VIOLENT DEATH THREAT LETTER AND DRAW that is still tacked up to his refrigerator. OUTSIDE: The SOUNDS of a RIOT in the making. Harvey rips down the threatening LETTER and throws it awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey BOUNDS down the stairs and into the shop. Cleve RU into the store, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: They're moving. I don't know where, but...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Did Jim call the press? (shouting at Danny) Get out there with your camera!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY NICCOLETTA
dialogues.text: I'm going!

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Press is covered. But we don't have a permit to march.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (digs for his bullhorn) When I got Coors out of the bars, the Union gave me this. I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: What do I do with this?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You're an activist. Take it. March them. (off Cleve, unsure) March those people up to the front doors of City Hall. When it looks really bad, the city's first gay Supervisor will come out and play peacemaker. We save the city from a riot. We can turn this night into more political power for the cause.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I can't do it like you do it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I won't always be here. Somebody else will have to take over. (looking him in the eye) I need you to be the scary one now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive, angry crowd has gathered. Baby-faced Cleve tak makeshift stage. He lifts the bullhorn and with nerves, r a speech. Its pages blow about. CLEVE'S POV: Harvey watches from afar. Encouraging him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Forty years ago tonight, the gay citizens of Germany found out they no longer had civil rights. Tomorrow morning, the gay citizens of Wichita will also awaken to find that they too have lost their civil rights. You have whistles. You use them when we have been attacked. Tonight we have been attacked. Initially Cleve is successful, but then the crowd turns, marching toward City Hall without him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck. Shit. Harvey! Cleve runs as fast as he can to cut through the crowd, to to the front. He gets on his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get the press to the overpass! ON HARVEY: Ducking through EMPTY STREETS, trying to get A OF THE CROWD and beat them to City Hall.
Cleve gets to the head of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Move... Left... Move... Left...

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: (charging up) What are you doing? Where's Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: We're shutting down traffic, both directions. Cleve looks up at the press that's arrived on the overpas above, and turns to two HIPPIE KIDS near the front.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Disconnect the power arms! The boys climb up a trolley and knock down the power arms Sparks fly. Brakes squeal. The press snaps photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The angry protesters march past the large glass windows o TWIN PEAKS bar. Unlike the Dade County march, the bar is empty. The patrons are already in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey RACES to his office. He stops at a mirror to straighten his tie and collect himself. OUTSIDE: The SOUND of the ANGRY MOB on City Hall's front steps. "Civil Rights or Civil War!" Someone THROWS A ROCK the City Hall doors. Harvey rushes out the front doors, pushing past the polic greet THE MOB on City Hall's front steps. Through the gla doors we see Cleve rush up and hand Harvey his bullhorn:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Harvey Milk, and I want to recruit you. (AN ENORMOUS CHEER rises) I want to recruit you for the fight to preserve our democracy against the Anita Bryants and John Briggs who are trying to legalize bigotry! We have a choice to make. The fight is at our doors. We must either go back in the closet and shut it tight, or fight... History shows (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: that if we continue to fight, we... will... win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Dick, Anne, Michael, Frank and Cleve are all in the office. The FRONT PAGE of the Examiner features a PICTURE CLEVE AND HARVEY ARM IN ARM on City Hall's steps. Cleve i jazzed. Harvey stews.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: They're calling it a "successful mediation." You're a God damn hero. Fuck. It came this close to a riot.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Lose the note cards next time. Your job is just to say into that bullhorn what they're all feeling.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: You're just jealous it wasn't you out there.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We're losing Prop Six by 60% and you're over there celebrating a riot. I need more visibility... (the real problem:) If we're going to beat this thing, we have to get Briggs to acknowledge us. Harvey steps away, hot, pensive. Anne gets quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Every paper's calling Prop Six the main event now. We lose this, we'll have anti-gay laws in all fifty states, and Briggs won't return our calls for a public debate.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: He's ignoring us to death.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (steaming back in) We need something populist. What's the number one complaint about city life?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: The piss smell in the Tenderloin.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Close.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK ROBINSON
dialogues.text: Dog shit.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: If you cleaned up all the dog shit in the city, you could be elected Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: "Mayor Milk."

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleve searches frantically for something... He SEES a pil DOG POOP. He scoops it up and runs it back to City Hall's front lawn and plants it in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE VERY SAME SPOT CLEVE JUST WAS: Harvey with a clump REPORTERS, a red and white "No on 6" button pinned to his lapel (HENCEFORTH, IT'S A FIXTURE).

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Dog mess is a hazard, and on top of that, it's disgusting. Under the ordinance, dog owners that don't clean up can be fined. This really is the bottom line! He smiles at his own joke, punctuating it by "accidentall stepping in Cleve's well-placed dog shit. A BIG grin. BUL FLASH. These flashes transition into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY STUDIES HIS OWN PHOTO on the FRONT PAGE of the Chronicle, making his announcement about dog poop. The SUPERVISORS are assembled for a vote. The CLERK, 60, wraps up his roll call

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Supervisor Lau?

dialogues.speaker: GORDON LAU
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Lau, Aye. Supervisor Silver?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL RUTH SILVER
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Silver, Aye. Supervisor White?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: White, No. Madam President, I have ten ayes and one no. Dianne Feinstein BANGS HER GAVEL down hard.

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE FEINSTEIN
dialogues.text: The San Francisco Gay Rights Ordinance sponsored by Supervisors Milk and Silver is passed.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA'S FLASH
dialogues.text: Harvey locks onto Dan White. Dan makes eye contact. Harve turns his attention to the chamber audience's applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gaggle of press has congregated. Mayor Moscone and Harv walk into the office keeping their conversation private.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: I can't get my stories on page ten, you're getting page one?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Doggy-doo's a real problem, George. With a shit eating grin, Harvey offers up a powder blue p

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Powder blue to sign they city's first Gay Rights law... George, we need your help with Briggs... The gay community will have your back from now on. On all issues. I hope you'll have ours. A beat between them. An alliance is forming. The Mayor si behind his desk and turns to the press with Harvey's pen.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: Good morning, everyone... I don't do this enough, taking swift and unambiguous action on a substantive move for civil rights. Moscone signs the law with the powder blue pen. Harvey le over him. THE PRESS CAPTURES THE MOMENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan sits at his desk, agitated. DAN'S POV: The FRONT PAGE the Examiner featuring MOSCONE AND HARVEY. Harvey comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What are you working on, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: If you have something to discuss, you can have your aide make an appointment with my aide.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Listen, I know you're disappointed about the Psychiatric Center... What else do you have coming up?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Now you need something from me. You want my me to join in with the Queers on this Prop Six business?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We prefer the word "gay," Dan. Just as I'm sure you prefer the word, "Irish-American" to "Mick."

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Harvey, our society can't exist without the family, without the church.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We're not against those things.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You're not? Can two men reproduce?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (a smile) No. But, we keep trying! (SERIOUSLY) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon, Dan. You're channeling Anita and Briggs... we can work together. On something...

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Okay. You introduce an initiative for Supervisor pay raises.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (anything but that) It's a bad time politically. I have an election next year.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You asked for something. Introduce pay raises. I can't take care of my family on our salaries. You don't have that problem, do you? Dan's AIDE steps into the doorway. She seems surprised to Harvey in Dan's office.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Milk, You'll excuse me, I have a development meeting. Dan goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd sings ГўВЂВњHappy Birthday.ГўВЂВќ One after anoth guests throw CREAM PIES in his face. RICK AND DAVID GOODS INCLUDED. A PEACE OFFERING. Harvey wipes pie from his eye In the B.G. the black drag queen sensation, SYLVESTER, br into his top 10 anthem, "You Make Me Feel." It's a who's of San Francisco's political elite. Jack scoots up to Har

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Taco Bell?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: Anne and Cleve tried to cut me out of your table. You should fire them.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'll take it under consideration. Why don't you get us a drink? A kiss and Jack heads to the bar. Scott approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Don't let Cezar Chavez hear you calling him Taco Bell.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: He's getting better. He's enrolling in classes on Monday. Scott wipes PIE CREAM from Harvey's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: I remember when your birthdays were a bit less... lavish. More intimate.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Who invited you? Anne?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: My boyfriend got an invitation. I was his "plus one."

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Congratulations. It was a tough ticket to get.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Congratulations to you. Looks like you're part of the Machine now. (Harvey looks away, toward Jack) You can do better.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: When I come home to Jack, I don't have to talk politics or talk intelligently. Or even talk. (SELF-DEPRECATING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where's an old man like me going to get such a good looking young man, right?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: You're not so old. You look handsome... Happy 48th. Looks like you're gonna make it to fifty after- all, Mr. Milk. Scott gives Harvey a BIRTHDAY KISS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, still wearing cream pie remnants on his jacket, w for Jack to come out of the rest room. Harvey's one of th last guests to leave. WAITERS are clearing tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPROACHES, footsteps ECHOING on the marble floor. Harvey braces himself.
Emerging from the shadows: DAN WHITE. He approaches Harve with a bottle of Chivas. Dan is SUPER-FRIENDLY, as if nothing unpleasant has ever happened between them.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Sorry I missed the party, Harv...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No problem, Dan. Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Dog poop?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: It's good! It's a good one.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Thanks. But it's a real problem.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. I mean, God knows how many problems it causes. All kinds of diseases, birth defects probably, I mean, stuff you can't even... (drifting off, drunkenly) Hey, I got you a little something.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You didn't have to--

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: (at the same time) You didn't have to-- (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do people always say that? "You didn't have to?" I mean, of course, right? But, that's what they always say. They always say things like that... Dan's attempts to be witty and erudite (like Harvey) only leave him confused and tongue tied. Harvey HAS NO IDEA why Dan is here.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Oh, what? Yeah, sure. Harvey, I just... I just want to say... Happy Birthday. Dan PUTS HIS ARMS AROUND HARVEY for a sort-of macho but really weird birthday hug. Harvey stiffens, it's such a peculiar moment. Dan steps back, looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've really learned a lot from watching you, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: No, I have. You gotta get out there. Get noticed. That's how it works. But, you have an issue. That's your advantage.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It's more than an issue, Dan. (a beat, one last try to get through to him) Dan. I've had four relationships in my life. Three of those four tried to kill themselves. I know it was my fault they did it. I told them to stay quiet. To hide. Most of my life I've been closeted. That's what living this life is like for most of us. The way things are... This isn't just about our jobs, or any issue, it's our lives we're fighting for. Jack emerges from the bathroom, barely together and leans Harvey. Dan steps back from Harvey and Jack, his moment alone stolen away.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I've learned a lot from you, Harvey. I'm going to get my picture in the papers, too. You'll see. I've got my own issue. That's right. Dan White's Got An Issue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOCK FOOTAGE: Along Market street: 375,000 people have s up for the parade, many holding signs naming their hometo Newark, San Antonio, Lincoln.

A MONTAGE: of the various marchers, floats, "Parents and Friends Of", high-camp drag queens, etc. Harvey sits on top of a car with a pink lei around his ne a fistful of white flowers in one hand, and in the other, hand written sign: "I'm from Woodmere, NY." To a news cam

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Come out! Just come on out! DRIVING THE CAR: Anne keeps a close eye on the parade watchers. Any one of them could be an assassin.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I see naked men walking around, naked women walking around, which doesn't bother me as far as my personal standards of nudity, but it's not proper. We wouldn't allow it for any other parade in San Francisco, and it should not be allowed for the gay parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just off stage. Anne hands him a typed postcard.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: It came in the mail today.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: "You get the first bullet the minute you stand at the microphone." (looking for a silver lining) Looks like the publicity's working.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: You don't have to go up there.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: It could happen any day, any night, any time... (off the ROARING CROWD that's waiting for him) The nation's eye is on us. I have to do this. JUMP TO: POV shots of cops and loners amongst the massive audience hint at Harvey's paranoia. Like diving off a cliff, Harvey launches up to the microphone. The deafening cheers surely would have drowne
out gunfire, but when it fades, He's standing. He deliver his impassioned call to action:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Harvey Milk, and I want to recruit you. I want to recruit you for the fight to preserve your democracy. Brothers and sisters, you must come out. Come out to your parents. I know that it is hard and will hurt them but think about how they will hurt you in the voting booth! Come out to your friends, if they indeed are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, to your fellow workers. Once and for all, break down the myths, destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake. For the sake of the youngsters who are becoming scared by the votes from Dade to Eugene. On the Statue of Liberty it says "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to be free." In the Declaration of Independence it is written "All men are created equal and are endowed with certain inalienable rights." For Mr. Briggs and Mrs. Bryant and all the bigots out there, no matter how hard you try, you cannot erase those words from the Declaration of Independence. No matter how hard you try, you cannot chip those words from off the base of the Statue of Liberty. That is what America is. Love it or leave it. Wild applause. He scans the crowd as he steps off stage. bit surprised to still be alive. Cleve grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: The Mayor says Briggs is on his way here. He could intercept him for us. We could get him face to face. He couldn't ignore us anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Get the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Briggs rides in a limo watching the ГўВЂВњfreaks" ou he nears the Parade Stages his POLICE ESCORTS take an unplanned turn. He leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: The parade is the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: They're taking us another way, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls in. Briggs cautiously steps out. Greeting are Moscone, the POLICE CHIEF, 25 SFPD officers, a gaggle press, and Harvey Milk. It's a showdown... HIGH NOON.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: I have a right to be here, Mr. Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's not in the interest of your safety, or my public's safety to let you into that parade grounds. Finally face to face, Harvey extends his hand. Its a show the FLASHING CAMERAS. Briggs is clearly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Harvey Milk. It's quite an honor to meet you, Mr. Briggs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: I'm aware. Sad you're too afraid to fight this out in public, Mr. Milk.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No sir. I would love to have a public debate. I'm very interested in the details of your argument.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: You know the details. As do the people. Look at the votes across this nation. The "public" is with me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Yes sir, today they are. But with my City's Mayor and the San Francisco press as my witnesses, I'm challenging you to a public debate. John nods, stiff. He can no longer avoid Harvey Milk. He back in his limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey sits with John Briggs at a table facing forward. W hear the cheers and jeers of the packed audience.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Senator, as a Christian it's interesting that you don't seem to understand what Christ was about. He was about accepting people and giving love, not carrying a Bible in one hand and hatred in the other... (cheers from the audience) ...Now all the gay myths have been shattered, all the fears, all the--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: Not in my mind they haven't--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: That's it. In your mind they haven't, and I'm wondering why--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: Mr. Milk, we don't allow people who believe in practicing bestiality to teach our children, and the reason we don't is because it is illegal. But it's not illegal to be a homosexual in California.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: And your law goes even further. Any school employee who even supports a gay person will be fired--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: True. But, gay people don't have children of their own. If they don't recruit our children, they'd all die away. That's why they want to be teachers, to encourage our children to join them.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: How do you teach homosexuality? Like French? I was born of heterosexual parents, I was taught by heterosexual teachers in a fiercely heterosexual society. So then why am I homosexual? And no offense meant, but if it were true that children mimicked their (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: teachers, you'd sure have a helluva lot more nuns running around. The audience eats it up. It feel like "The Harvey Milk Sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs makes a STATEMENT to the press.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: If they're going to lead such an open life of homosexuality that they want a 21-gun salute every time somebody goes by them, those people are going to be in danger of being removed their job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuing on with his recorded will...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We were really genuinely frightened by Proposition Six, and with the backlash gaining strength, we were very pessimistic. We didn't think there was any chance we could beat it. What we hoped to do was to organize to the point that when we did lose, there would be a revolt... That all hell would break lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, pacing, decisive.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: People are coming out, though. We met with groups in Bakersfield, Redding, a dozen people showed up in a library basement in Fresno asking for our support if they came out. Last Sunday, the Reverend of St. Mary's came out to his entire congregation...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: We're still losing, 60 to 30. We have to take the show on the road. Call Briggs's office. Do a press release. Tell them he can pick the town, the audience, and I'll ask our supporters not to attend.

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: Their audiences are insanely devout. We'll get killed.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Get me Orange County.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is FLIPPING OUT, storming around the place.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: You just have to go down to LA and guess the right things on TV and they'll pay us... You have to use your fame now while you have it. We could have nice things.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I don't have time to do game shows right now... This stops Jack cold.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: You are horrible! I have worked on this surprise for you for weeks!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Are you drunk right now?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: You are an ungrateful asshole!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Jack, I'll have more time soon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: You're ashamed of me!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: That's not true. I think you're smart. You're capable. No matter what your family or your father said. I believe in you... We should figure out something for you to do. I could get you a job.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: I'll never be good enough for you! Jack THROWS A PIECE OF POTTERY AT HARVEY. It misses, CRAS THROUGH THE WINDOW onto the street below.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'll get a broom. Harvey goes. Jack collapses into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV CAMERAS ROLL. They've gotten their ORANGE COUNTY DEBAT BRIGGS'S SUPPORTERS jeer Harvey as he rips into their Sta Senator. Their vehemence frightens Dick in the audience. Harvey lifts a Briggs flier.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: If in your statements here you say that child molestation is not an issue, why do you put out literature that hammers it home, why do you play on that myth and fear?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: Same thing with VD Harvey, we put out publications about VD so you can avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (with a grin) But you've even admitted that there's more molestation in the heterosexual group! So why not get rid of the heterosexual teachers? Boos from the conservative audience.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: We are not talking about homos... child molestation, the fact is, at least 95 percent of the people are heterosexual. If we took heterosexuals out AND homosexuals out, you know what--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --we'd have no teachers We'd have no teachers--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: --No child molestation... So you're saying the percentage of population is equal to the percentage of child molestation?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: (getting more lost) No, no, I'm not saying that at all--

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: That's what you just said.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BRIGGS
dialogues.text: No. I'm saying that we cannot prevent child molestation so let's cut our odds down and take out the homosexual group and keep in the heterosexual group-- Harvey laughs in disbelief at the asinine argument. Brigg looks down to his notes, lost. Harvey takes the opportuni to rip into the State Senator:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (directly to Briggs) --Sir, in your own drive for personal power, how many careers are you willing to see destroyed? How many lives will you destroy in your lust for power, and when will you stop? The crowd boos, rails. This isn't San Francisco, it's Ora County. In the audience, Dick Pabich sweats, taken aback the level of hatred. Harvey tries to maintain his composu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey heads home from work. He starts into his store. He sees JACK LIRA'S SHADOW through the curtains upstairs, turns instead to the cafe next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey sits down at the bar. The WAITER pours a coffee fo him. Harvey looks up to the TV. HARVEY'S POV: DAN WHITE ON TV talking to a news reporter. feels as if Dan is talking directly to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: All I'm really saying is, if we don't protect ourselves with this kind of legislation, a transvestite can show up at a public school with all the qualifications for teaching and they can't refuse to hire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey rushes from a packed session in the Supervisors' Chambers to his office. Anne is behind him. He picks up t phone. It seems urgent.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Hey Jack, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just want to know when you'll be home.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You just had them pull me out of my big vote on the dog shit ordinance. Did you do this on purpose, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: It's poop, Harvey. Aren't I more important than poop?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Yes, but... I don't know when I'll be home. Maybe 6. 6:15.

dialogues.speaker: JACK LIRA
dialogues.text: Fine. 6:15. Harvey hangs up. His patience is slipping. He looks up in time to see Dan heading down the hall with his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey catches up to Dan who is on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Dan? How's the baby?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You didn't bring up Supervisor pay raises. In fact, I heard you plan to publicly oppose them.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I heard you planned to vote against them too, Dan. Were you trying to set me up?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: (parrotting Harvey

dialogues.speaker: EARLIER
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's not a good time for me to bring it up. Politically.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Dan, there's a vote to approve the police desegregation settlement, give me that and I'll consider backing pay raises.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: (suddenly very dark) I don't trade votes... unlike you, the way I was raised, we believe in right and wrong. Moral and immoral.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Black skin and White in your police department? (Dan steams) Dan, even Ronald Reagan's come out against Proposition Six. You're looking more and more out of touch.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: If I come out against Prop Six, it's only for the invasion of State's rights issue.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (smiles, trying to lighten) And the potential witch hunts against you "straight people," right? Dan tries hard to come up with a cogent response. He can' His behavior is alarming. He sets down his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You underestimate me, Milk. You're very, very wrong about me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean. A moment. Dan is on the verge of tears, hot angry tears.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it, Dan? You can tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You don't... You can't humiliate me. And you will not demean me.
Anne appears down the hall. Dan has more on his mind, but moment has passed. He picks up his briefcase and walks ou the building. Off Harvey, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks home. A PASSERBY shouts:

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: You're the asshole that just passed that dog shit thing aren't you? What the hell do you have against dogs?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (with his trademark charm) Sir, blind people can't see "shit." What the heck do you have against blind people? The young folks surrounding the PASSERBY laugh and hoot a Harvey's joke. Even the harassing PASSERBY can't help but crack a grin. Harvey beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening the door, Harvey finds a trail of voter registrat cards, anti-Briggs literature, and Coors beer cans. Pushi through his fear, he carefully follows the cans and flyer the stairs and through his apartment. Odd notes are taped to the walls. They all lead to a blac velvet curtain with a note attached: "YOU'VE ALWAYS LOVED

dialogues.speaker: CIRCUS, HARVEY, WHAT DO YOU THINK OF MY LAST ACT
dialogues.text: Harvey pulls back the curtain to find Jack's body, cold a discolored, hanging from a beam by a noose. HARVEY CAN'T MOVE. He is mesmerized... horrified. He grabs a knife and frantically tries cutting Jack down. cuts through the rope and FALLS TO THE FLOOR with the HEA BODY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott arrives. Sitting very still, Harvey is being consol by Cleve and Anne. Tears in his eyes, Harvey won't look u

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey. Look at me. Look at me. You did everything you could.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: No, I didn't. Not everything...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: What else could you have done?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I could have come home at six o'clock, not six-fifteen. Scott puts his arm around Harvey. Harvey buries his head. Anne helps Cleve take down Jack's many hidden notes. Clev quietly reads a prominently placed one:

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: "Beware. The ides. Of November."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the recorder as if re-living the event over again...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Jack was gone. I didn't have time to mourn... There was no choice but to keep on... to keep fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey sits in a make-up chair. A MAKE-UP artist is paint him up to look like a clown. Several other CITY OFFICIALS in chairs beyond him. Harvey turns to the make-up artist. With sincere enthusiasm:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Thank you for this great honor. But do you think once the magazine is done snapping pictures, maybe I could keep the suit for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still made up from head to toe as a clown, Harvey walks t streets of San Francisco. He waves, smiles, poses for pho with tourists. It's a rare moment of grace. He jumps on a trolley headed toward Castro. He instantly captures the imagination of a small GIRL wearing a knit hat.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (re: their hats) Would you like to trade with me?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No. What the heck are you?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Oh, me? I'm an elected official. I run this city.
He makes a show of it. She smiles. He hands her the flowe he's been holding onto all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIS IS THE MOMENT. Harvey watches aides on the phones co districts for voting results. Jim fills up a map on the w

dialogues.speaker: DICK PABICH
dialogues.text: San Bernadino is coming in. Not good.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Of course not. How not good?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL WONG
dialogues.text: 60% for Briggs. Same in Fresno.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Dear God, little Lotus Blossom. Harvey is stunned. Other districts follow with similar results. They go up in red on the map.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: Imperial is 69% "for" so far.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Put it up on the board. Harvey tries to stomach this major defeat, loss after los He starts reflexively tying his tie in a knot. Cleve come to Harvey, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The whole world is watching this. This is San Francisco we're about to lose. Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I can have 15,000 people in an hour. But there's gonna be riots if this thing passes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (darkens, pointed) There goddamn better be.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: (stops, a beat, then:) What are you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I can't say it because I'm a public official, but for God's sake, if this thing passes, fight back. Cleve is stunned, holding the weight of Harvey's words. Harvey's focus is interrupted when Anne brings him the ph

dialogues.speaker: ANNE KRONENBERG
dialogues.text: Don Amador down in LA.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (reluctantly answers) Kind of a bad time, Don.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No sir, this is Paul. Don just gave me the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Paul who?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You talked to me on the phone a year or so ago. I'm from Minnesota... I'm in a wheelchair. REVEAL: The boy in his wheelchair on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (a beat to take it in, then:) I thought you were a goner, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I should have called. When I read in the paper that you won the Supervisor seat, I got a friend to put me on a bus to LA.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Who did you know in Los Angeles?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEEN
dialogues.text: Nobody. That's the uh... I just didn't want to die anymore, sir. (Harvey's at a loss for words) I met your friend Don down here. I turned 18. I voted today against Prop Six... Thank you, Mr. Milk.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: No. You did this all by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEEN
dialogues.text: I don't think I'd be alive right now without you, sir. You were right about LA. It's like gay Disney World.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Then you have to see San Francisco!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG TEEN
dialogues.text: Okay. I will. Don wanted me to um... congratulate you on what he says looks like a big win for us tonight. Congratulations Mr. Milk. Harvey turns back to the map. Jim Rivaldo is now coloring LA county with green. On the other end of the phone, Harv friend in LA, Don Amador, is back on the line.

dialogues.speaker: DON AMADOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It looks like we've taken LA County, Harvey. By 65%. It's huge.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I gotta go, Don. Thank you. (frantic, to the room) LA by 65% put it up! Put it up! The tone in the room is changing. Jim storms up.

dialogues.speaker: JIM RIVALDO
dialogues.text: The polls were off. Briggs is going down by more than 2 to 1. The only district where it's leading in San Francisco is Dan White's. Harvey takes a moment to absorb the map. Anne, Dick & all the volunteers. What this apparent win means to him, his people. To Cleve:

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Well crap Cleve, now what are we going to do tonight?! (re: a giant, jock strap wearing, Lady Liberty) Cover up Lady Liberty. The cameras will be coming our way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV cameras roll. Lady liberty is covered with a "No on Si poster. A brass band marches dramatically into the hall. Balloons fall. Harvey MOUNTS the stage to INCREDIBLE CHEE

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: To the gay community all over this state... my message to you is... so far a lot of people joined us and rejected Proposition Six, and now we owe them something... We must destroy the myths once and for all, shatter them. We must continue to speak out... and most importantly, most importantly, every gay person must come out. (CHEERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight... Tonight it is clear that everyone out there does know one of us. And now that they do, they see we are not sick... they can feel we are not wrong... and they know we should have a place in this great country and in this world... A message of hope has been to sent to all the young people out there... to all those afraid of this wave of hate... to all those who have lost their homes and their hometowns... tonight we know there is a place for us! My brothers and sisters... we can come home again! The crowd goes WILD. Harvey BEAMS. Moscone walks up onto stage and lifts Harvey's hand. Harvey is now a member of S.F. political elite. Cleve watches from afar as Harvey s off and disappears into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan watches HARVEY'S VICTORY SPEECH on the local news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party behind him, Harvey scans the block. Cleve catch up, looking at Harvey, probing:

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You ever heard of sore losers? Well, I'm a sore winner... I thought we were goners. (HALF-JOKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd started looking forward to the riots.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: I told you, I don't "do" losing.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I think maybe we're best with our backs to the wall. It's too quiet. (a new idea, what's next) I think we should march on Washington D.C. next year.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: Milk, you're a decent politician, a mediocre businessman, but you're a lousy gay man. (Harvey knows what he's getting at) Take some time off. Fifty's right around the corner. (a devilish grin) Nobody will want you after that... I can handle D.C.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (smiles, incredulous) The people voted for us, Cleve Jones.

dialogues.speaker: CLEVE JONES
dialogues.text: They did. There's nowhere to march tonight, Mr. Harvey Milk. Lets go back inside. Turning back, they savor the moment, like father and son walking to Castro Camera, growing ever smaller in the fra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan White slides a sealed letter across a desk to an Aide It's addressed to Moscone. He seems oddly calm.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Could you give this to the Mayor for me? As soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks down the hallway to his office, a spring in step. There are nods, hellos if not outright deference fr most passersby. His newfound political muscle is evident. He comes face to face with Dan White.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Morning, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I just resigned. Congratulations. I'm sure you're pleased. Harvey doesn't know what to say. Dan's right, it does mak him happy. But it's not that simple.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll be the next President of the Board.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'm sure we could work together-- Dan walks away from Harvey. He doesn't want to hear anyth Harvey has to say. Harvey watches as Dan is met in the hallway by an OFFICER from the POLICE OFFICERS ASSOCIATION.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Hey, Dan. Just got word. Can we talk to you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Sure... Dan heads for his office.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Downstairs. The Association meeting room... Harvey watches as Dan follows the officer down the stairs an ASSOCIATION MEETING ROOM on the next floor. When the D OPENS, Harvey sees SEVERAL REPRESENTATIVES from the Polic Department wearing somber expressions. It looks as if Dan is about to get REAMED OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACTUAL FOOTAGE: Channel 5 reporting from Dan White's stre

dialogues.speaker: DAVID FOWLER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Most people were surprised when Dan White quit last Friday citing financial difficulties. Now we've heard that White is asking for his Supervisor job back. But many say--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, watching on the small TV set in his office.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID FOWLER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: --White gave up all of his political chits when he resigned without making any arrangements. The news story transitions in the B.G. as Harvey gets up.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (ON TV/BG)
dialogues.text: The city of San Francisco is in disbelief. Four-hundred bodies have been found thus far in Jonestown, Guyana. Leader of the People's Temple, Jim Jones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey heads to Dan's office. He toys with the nameplate. Something bittersweet lingers. He walks in. HARVEY'S POV: On City Hall's lawn, Dan is with the press. looks up, seeing Harvey in his office window. They make eye contact. It bears all the awkwardness of a relationship lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's snapped. With adolescent frustration in evide Dan is with his wife, the press and a few supporters.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: It was a major decision on Friday that I had to come... to arrive at. But since that time, people unknown to me, plus my family and friends, have come to me and stated that they want me to stay in office, that they support me... So I'm asking the Mayor to let me stay in office to serve the people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is firm, his hands planted on the Mayor's desk.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: He gets dragged into a closed door meeting with the Police Officers Association, and comes out demanding his job back? What do you think they promised him? Or worse, how did they threaten him?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: A man has the right to change his mind. Give me some peace.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: How many of our propositions has Dan shut down? We could finally settle this police desegregation nonsense. Cement rent control. It's his vote on this Board that stands in our way.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: I get it, Harvey. I've been lobbied all week. Enough.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Let me just remind you that you're up for re-election. If you re- appoint Dan, you lose the gay vote. They listen to me. You won't get elected dog catcher.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: (stern, silent, a beat, then:) I'll make my decision on Monday. (as Harvey's on his way out, with a wry grin) You know what you sounded like just now? Boss Tweed or Mayor Daly.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (returns the smile) A "homosexual" with a bit of power... rather scary isn't it, Mr. Mayor? OFF Harvey. He's come a long way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey sits in a balcony seat of the filled, darkened ope house next to Brazilian opera star BIDU SAYAO, 76. He's enraptured by a production of TOSCA. ON STAGE IT'S "O Scarpia, we shall meet before God!" Refu to be taken prisoner, Tosca jumps from the walls of the castle set to her death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Ann offers the phone to Dan. Dan takes it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Yes. This is Dan White.

dialogues.speaker: KCBS REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm Barbra Taylor from KCBS. I'm interested in your reaction. I've received information from the Mayor's office that you won't be getting your job back.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't know anything about that. Dan hangs up on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey can't sleep. He dials the phone. He lets it ring a ring. Finally, a voice picks up on the other line.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Hello? REVEAL: Scott, half asleep.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Sorry to wake you up.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I went to the opera tonight. Guess who my date was.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Bidu Sayao herself. She was in the first Puccini I ever saw. The crowd went wild. It was like I was young again, seeing my first live opera...

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: If you go to the opera again, you should call me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Really? Scott gets out of bed, considers his words. It's intimate

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes. I'd go with you.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I'd like that. Harvey is quiet, a rare moment of reflection. An unexpect tear rolls down his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Look out the window, the sun's coming up.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: It's late. You should get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I don't want to miss it.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: Miss what?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: This. Harvey's single word answer means, "Life." OFF Harvey: Neither wants to hang up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rising in his own living room, Dan White has been all night, too. The coffee table is covered with coke can and junk food wrappers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for a MAN inside to turn away, Dan sneaks in thro a side window at City Hall. The man calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute, Mr.--

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: My aide was supposed to come down here and let me in the side door, but she never showed up.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: I'm Dan White. City Supervisor. We follow Dan down the hall and into the grand entry-way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks through City Hall's METAL DETECTORS. He pick his keys from the dish and heads up the grand staircase. ships in the night, Harvey just misses Dan exiting the elevator. Dan heads into Mayor Moscone's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Dianne, Harvey is thrilled, rubbing it in.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Who's it gonna be? Is he replacing Dan with that God Damned liberal lefty Don Horanzy? That'll really shake up the Board, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DIANNE FEINSTEIN
dialogues.text: All I know is that we're getting a new Supervisor today. If Dan shows up, just avoid him. We don't need a scene today, right Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: (grins ear to ear) Heaven forbid, Dianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAYOR'S SECRETARY sits at her desk. Shouting can be h from inside his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moscone leads Dan White to the bar beside his office. Dan enraged. Moscone lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: You can't take this away from me! Moscone has his back turned, pouring them cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR MOSCONE
dialogues.text: The issue is what's fair, for the people of your district. Take some time off. Spend it with your family.
Moscone finishes pouring two cocktails, and turns to see White brandishing his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moscone's Secretary, and a WAITING MAN note the THREE DUL THUDS, not so different than a backfire. The secretary lo out the window, concerned. The waiting man checks his wat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still gripped in his hand, Moscone's cigarette burns a ho in his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan walks past Dick Pabich, past Dianne's office. Harvey' voice can be heard down the hall. He sounds up-beat,

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This time next year we're marching on Washington D.C. It'll look like Market and Castro, but with a million people. Write that down. Tell President Carter we're coming after him next. I'm going to deposit this. I'll be back in 20 minutes. Dan arrives at Harvey's office door. Harvey is with a FRI preparing to leave, surprised to see Dan in his doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DAN WHITE
dialogues.text: Say, Harve, can I see you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Sure. Dan walks Harvey down the hall to his old office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey walks in first. Dan stays between Harvey and the d Dan closes it. Harvey smiles, sensing something is off. Dan draws his revolver. Harvey raises his hand. Dan Fires The bullet rips through Harvey's hand and down his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: Oh no... N-- Dan Fires again, silencing Harvey's cry for help.

Harvey turns away. Another bullet rips into his chest, an falls to his knees, now facing the window. He staggers to it. The moment is extended as we see Harvey's POV of the Opera House outside the window, and the Castro beyond it. HOLD ON HARVEY, gazing out at his beloved city. Dan puts his revolver to the back of Harvey's head. HE FI And just like that, Harvey falls.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Last week I got a phone call--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is still speaking into the tape recorder...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: --from Altoona, Pennsylvania, and the voice was quite young, and the person said... "Thanks." You've got to elect gay people so that that young child and the thousands upon thousand like him know there's hope... hope for a better world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott and Anne enter a sparsely attended memorial service Most of the seats are empty. The speaker is unfamiliar, s appointed CITY OFFICIAL.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT SMITH
dialogues.text: (finally crumbling, tears roll) Where is everybody? Didn't anyone give a damn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey speaking into the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: I ask this... If there should be an assassination, I would hope that five, ten, one hundred, a thousand would rise. I would like to see every gay lawyer, every gay architect come out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking back out onto the street, Anne and Scott turn to down Market Street, the camera pans and drifts to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: A MASSIVE CANDLELIGHT MARCH. CLEVE JONES LEADS TENS OF
dialogues.text: THOUSANDS of San Franciscans of every religion, nationali sexuality, all of the familiar faces and many new ones... THEY ALL MARCH SILENTLY up Market Street to the palace Ha dreamed could be his own: City Hall.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --If a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy every closet door... And that's all. I ask for the movement to continue. Because it's not about personal gain, not about ego, not about power... it's about the "us's" out there. Not only gays, but the Blacks, the Asians, the disabled, the seniors, the us's. Without hope, the us's give up-- As the thousands of mourners arrive at City Hall, they pl their candles around the statue of Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --I know you cannot live on hope alone, but without it, life is not worth living. So you, and you, and you...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY MILK
dialogues.text: You gotta give em' hope... you gotta give em' hope. Harvey closes his note pad, puts down his pencil, and pus stop on his recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Push in on Castro Camera. The sign still in the window, "We're Very Open." FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: RETURNED TO SAN FRANCISCO AND COMMITTED SUICIDE.
dialogues.text: AS CREDITS ROLL: The following updates are accompanied by images of the actual people from 1977 to current day:
